I am stuck pxe booting my 1st vm. I am using VMware Workstation. I'm assuming from erading this I need to update the dhcp config for vmware workstations ```ensure your test Machine is on the same Layer 2 subnet as your DRP endpoint, or that you’ve configured your networks IP Helper to forward your DHCP requests to your DRP Endpoint```

<@UAQAE0VNE> the DRP Endpoint needs to be able to reach the Machine (VM) being provisioned via the network.  If you are using a virtualized environment, you often have to be aware/concerned with the DHCP services on the Layer 2 network your Machine is on.  In many case, the hypervisor management pieces will run DHCP, which can interfere with the provisioning aspects.   DRP Endpoint can be "The DHCP" service (configure it via the Networks/Subnets pieces), or an external DHCP service can be used, however, the DHCP server needs to be configured to support the DHCP options for Next Boot and Boot File appropriately.

The easiest initial test environment is to insure that the DRP Endpoint and the Machine being provisioned are on the same Layer 2 network, and that no other DHCP services are competing on that same Layer 2 subnet.  It is NOT a requirement that the DHCP service be in this L2 segment exclusively - but it's the easiest path that does not require or need to have network equipment set up to properly DHCP Relay the requests _to_ the DRP Endpoint

It's been a while since I used VMware Workstation (I use VirtualBox) - but I do know that VirtualBox interferes by forcing a DHCP service to run on the virtual network segments.  Turning it off is usually the best course of action.  It's entirely probably that Workstation has a similar construct which may be interfering with your ability to successfully provision in the virtual network environment
yep been looking into it
ty

It _may_ be possible that using our DHCP service in "Proxy" mode will work if you have an existing DHCP service on the network - however, not guaranteed.  When you add a Subnet, setthe "Proxy DHCP" option to enable (yes) - it works in conjunction with a "broken" or incorrectly configured DHCP (sometimes ... :slightly_smiling_face: ).
we do recommend NOT using Proxy DHCP unless you really need it, as it isn't always reliable compared to correctly configured DHCP services
Is there a way to re-run discovery if a machine is in sledgehammer but for some reason it hasn't sent discovery info to the server?
and as we discovered, dhcp option nextserver is not in the rfc so no guarantee it'll work
<@U9BU09D51>... well ... just reboot the machine w/ the Workflow still set to Discovery - and it should re-run.
what do you mean by "hasn't sent discovery info" ?  did a Machine object NOT get created?   or did gohai NOT run?  what do you mean by that statement ?
A machine object didn't get created

never heard of or seen that happen before ... you're sure the Machine that booted in to Sledgehammer booted in to Sledgehammer served by THAT DRP endpoint ?   i.e. you don't have multiple endpoints that might have answered ?
I checked the other endpoint that might have answered, I don't see it there either.
I've been having weird problems with dr-provision seeming to crash and restart on the server, I'm not sure if that's the issue here or not.

hmm ... generally, things are pretty stable unless you've hit an odd bug - and if you have, we'd like to know about it, so we can either fix it, or point out the fix was done (IIRC, you're on v3.8.0 )
if you're capturing the `stdout` logfile info - we'd like to see that after a suspected crash

I think it's all dumping to syslog so I'll have to see if I can find anything.  But what I was seeing yesterday was that I wasn't able to connect to the UX.  When I logged in to the server, dr-provision wasn't running.  I poked around looking for logs to tell me what had happened, then when I looked again later dr-provision had seemed to restart on its own (or been restarted by systemd).  This happened a few times around the time I was trying to get a host to discover.
One thing I remember seeing in the logs was dr-provisiong getting the "GOAWAY" signal (which I didn't even know was a signal...) and shutting down.  But it wasn't consistent.
ok - if you can find more detail around those time frames / log entries - would be appreciated
I don't see anything in the logs.  I see traffic going back and forth between the server and this system that is sitting at the sledgehammer prompt, but the machine object never gets created.
LOL mystery solved.
The system already existed in dr-provision.  So that's why a new system wasn't showing up.
<@U9BU09D51> check your VM clock setting, just in case.  too much shift and the certificates fail
you may want to test the DRPCLI from inside the VM
Hrm ok
^^ now seeing you solved it.  good work
I've been digging in to my issue a little further
My VM TFTP's ipxe.efi/ipxe.pxe and unpacks the ROM. It seems to fail to ifopen and/or dhcp from there

Manually opening ipxe command shell and issuing an "ifopen && dhcp" and then chain loading "//IP:PORT/default.ipxe" works. IPXe chain loads sledgehammer, auto discovery + provisioning works, and my centos 7 workflow/install completes with no problem
Any ideas to why ipxe is failing to open without manual intervention?

text: hm
so
the code relies on all bootenvs that install an OS to have -install as the last part of their name.
so `"Name": "centos-7-install-update",` will not work out well. :confused:
`"Name": "centos-7-update-install"` will work better.

```May 24 13:48:22 ubuntu dr-provision[7092]: dr-provision2018/05/24 20:48:22.006224 [280:13]static [error]: /home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/digitalrebar/provision/midlayer/tftp.go:82
May 24 13:48:22 ubuntu dr-provision[7092]: [280:13]TFTP: lpxelinux.0: transfer error: sending block 0: code=0, error: TFTP Aborted
```
Im stuck for now
One of those per file read is expected.
(read via tftp)
It is the firmware starting a transver, getting the total size to be transferred, and then aborting the transfer while it goes off and creates a buffer big enough to hold the file to be transferred.

you have 128/24 as the last octet in the available range, but  .10 -> .100 as the range to make available to leases.

Hey there, I'm curious how sledgehammer determines the hostname.  It looks like if it doesn't get a hostname from dhcp it does a getent on the IP address.  What exactly does getent do?

<@U9BU09D51> I couldn't find the relevant code that generates it (I just saw it a few days ago ...!) - but yeah, basically if nothing is specified via DHCP Reservation, then the hostname defaults to a `d` followed by a dash separated MAC address of the provisioning interface on the machine ... the `d` was injected to make sure the name did not start with a number
